header.abstract: The Wilson W. Wyatt papers (dated 1826-1993; 150.23 cubic feet; 476 boxes) consists of materials relating to Wilson W. Wyatt's personal and political life, including his career a lawyer, a mayor, a lieutenant governor, and a political aide.

descriptive_summary.author: Processed by Jeff Suchanek; Machine-readable finding aid created by Haruko Nakamura.
descriptive_summary.title: Wilson W. Wyatt papers
descriptive_summary.creator: Wyatt, Wilson W. (Wilson Watkins), 1905-1996
descriptive_summary.arrangement: Collection is arranged into nine series by format: Legal Series, Political Series, Personal Series, Anne D. Wyatt Series, Duplicate Clippings, Miscellaneous Publications, and Office Rolodex Series, Memorabilia Series, Photograph Series, Scrapbook and Guest Registry Series, Audio-visual Series, and the Addition Series.

descriptive_summary.prefercite: 95m4: [identification of item], Wilson W. Wyatt papers, 1826-1993, University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Wilson W. Wyatt, son of Richard H. and Mary Watkins Wyatt, was born on November 21, 1905, in Louisville, Kentucky. A graduate of Louisville's Male High School and the Jefferson School of Law, he was admitted to the Kentucky bar in 1927 and began his practice in his native city. On June 14, 1930, he married Anne Kinnaird Duncan. He served as secretary to the Kentucky Bar Association from 1930 to 1934 before founding the law firm of Peter, Heyburn, Marshall and Wyatt in 1935. Wyatt became the principal legal counsel for the largest Kentucky newspaper, the Louisville Courier-Journal, and a friend of the newspaper's owner, Robert Worth Bingham.

At Bingham's urging, Wyatt successfully ran for mayor of Louisville in 1941 and took office only days before the United State's entry into World War II. As an ardent New Deal Democratic mayor, Wyatt oversaw the transformation of Louisville's business district to a wartime footing, and worked with the Kentucky General Assembly to modernize and streamline Louisville's city government. During the war years Wyatt became a leading spokesperson for many national civic and public service organizations including the American Society of Planning Officials and the National Municipal League. He became the subject of numerous newspaper and magazine articles which detailed his ideas on governmental and municipal planning, which came to the attention of the White House. In the Spring of 1943, President Franklin D. Roosevelt tapped Wyatt to head an important mission to North Africa on behalf of the Board of Economic Warfare to draw up plans to coordinate economic development in that region to aid the war effort.

After his mayoral term ended, President Harry S. Truman appointed Wyatt housing expediter in the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion in January of 1946. Wyatt's New Deal philosophy in dealing with the problem of affordable housing for returning veterans came under fire from the Republican controlled Congress. Upon receiving little support from the White House, Wyatt resigned as housing expediter in December of 1946.

Upon his return to Louisville, Wyatt founded the law firm Wyatt and Grafton, and although a successful practicing attorney he maintained his involvement in national politics. In 1947 he became the first chairman of Americans for Democratic Action (ADA), an organization founded by Eleanor Roosevelt, Joe Rauh, Arthur Schlesinger, Jr., Wyatt and other leading liberals, to keep alive the spirit of the New Deal against the backlash of the policies of the Republican controlled Congress. In 1952 Wyatt continued his involvement in national politics by managing Adlai Stevenson's unsuccessful campaign for the presidency against General Dwight D. Eisenhower. Wyatt also was a close advisor during Stevenson's 1956 presidential campaign.

In 1958 Wyatt declared his candidacy for the office of governor of Kentucky. In the spring of 1959 in a move to enhance unity within the Democratic party, he withdrew from the governor's race and agreed to run for lieutenant governor on a united Democratic ticket with Bert T. Combs. The Combs-Wyatt ticket defeated Harry Lee Waterfield, in the Democratic primary, and won handily in the fall election. During his term as lieutenant governor, Wyatt served as chairman of the Kentucky Economic Development Commission which provided new impetus in drawing new industry and businesses to Kentucky. Wyatt also was the force behind the establishment of the Spindletop Research Center, a think-tank/technology center affiliated with the University of Kentucky.

In 1962 Wyatt ran for the U.S. Senate against the Republican incumbent, Thruston B. Morton. In a hard fought and often bitter campaign, Wyatt narrowly lost the election. In 1963 President John F. Kennedy sent Wyatt to Indonesia to mediate a dispute between U.S. oil companies and Indonesian President Sukarno. Sukarno had threatened to nationalize foreign oil operations, but after delivering a personnel message from President Kennedy, Wyatt was successful in negotiating an agreement.

After his term as lieutenant governor ended, Wyatt returned to Louisville and established one of the largest and most prestigious law firms in the state, the firm Wyatt, Tarrant & Combs. A close friend of Hubert H. Humphrey since their tenure as mayors, Wyatt was asked to play an important role at the 1968 Democratic National Convention. Under his guidance, a compromise was reached between the hawks and the doves regarding the Democratic party's Vietnam War plank. After leaving public office, Wyatt remained a civic leader in Louisville and advisor to presidential candidates, governors, and mayors until his death on June 11, 1996. He is buried in Cave Hill Cemetery in Louisville.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Wilson W. Wyatt papers (dated 1826-1993; 150.23 cubic feet; 476 boxes) consists of materials relating to Wilson W. Wyatt's personal and political life, including his career a lawyer, a mayor, a lieutenant governor, and a political aide. The items document his continued interest in politics after his retirement as well. Also included in this collection are materials that relate to Mrs. Anne D. Wyatt's personal and public life.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Political Series, the largest in the collection, contains materials generated and collected by Lieutenant Governor Wyatt from his involvement in Louisville politics and the Al Smith presidential campaign in 1928 up to and including the 1992 presidential campaign of Bill Clinton. It is divided into six sub-series which are arranged alphabetically by subject

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This small series mainly documents Lieutenant Governor Wyatt's legal career from 1927 to his election as Mayor of Louisville in 1941, and his participation on the U.S. Circuit Judge Nominating Commission for the Sixth Circuit in 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This large series documents Lieutenant Governor Wyatt's involvement in many Louisville and state civic activities, private clubs and organizations to which he belonged, personal correspondence he sent and received, business pertaining to farms he owned in Kentucky and Tennessee, and the wills and estates of family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series documents Anne Wyatt's political involvement in the Democratic Women's Club of Kentucky, as well some personal material and family history information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains campaign-related material including posters, buttons, Democratic National Convention passes and tickets, as well as state and civic awards presented to Lieutenant Governor Wyatt during the course of his political and civic career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs from many aspects of Lieutenant Governor Wyatt's political and civic career, as well as his personal life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series focuses mainly on Lieutenant Governor Wyatt's early political career as Mayor of Louisville to his election as Lieutenant Governor of Kentucky. There is one scrapbook which documents Wyatt's life up until his election as Mayor of Louisville. The Guest registers are from the Lieutenant Governor's mansion in Frankfort, Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Addition series (dated 1919-1980, undated; .23 cubic feet; 1 boxes) comprise correspondence, personal items, publicity items, clippings, photographs, and memorabilia owned or created by Wilson Wyatt. The Photograph Information and Descriptions folder contains assorted photograph descriptions of unknown photographs.
